forecast.rationale: My forecast is based on the current state of the MLB batting races and the historical difficulty of achieving a .400 batting average. As of mid-May, the highest average is Freddie Freeman's .375. Closing the 25-point gap to .400 in just 13 days is a formidable challenge, requiring a player to hit at an extremely high, likely unsustainable, pace (e.g., .500) for roughly a dozen games. While not impossible, it is a very low-probability event. Typically, as the season progresses, batting averages regress toward established norms, making it harder to maintain such a high mark. The status quo, with no player currently hitting .400, is the strongest predictor. The forecast is not lower than 5% because an elite hitter is capable of an exceptional two-week hot streak. The forecast is not higher because of the significant statistical leap required in a short period against major league pitching. I would raise my probability if Freeman or another hitter had several multi-hit games in the coming week, and lower it if their averages dip even slightly.
